Jeyne: so basically you say “wig” when someone says something super epic or cool

[later]

Daenerys: i’ve been meaning to tell you this for the longest time, but…i’m in love with you, sansa

Sansa: wig

summary: Dazzled by the New - Silberias - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
title: Dazzled by the New - Silberias - Game of Thrones (TV) [Archive of Our Own]
excerpt: An Archive of Our Own, a project of the Organization for Transformative Works
description: Arya and Gendry rescue Sansa from the Red Keep shortly after Ned’s execution, and the three eventually make their way down to Dorne. Arya is the brains, Gendry works as a smith, and Sansa strums her little harp and sings pretty songs–catching the eye of Prince Oberyn Martell once they reach Dorne puts all of them on a course of reunion with their pasts but none of them want to leave that past behind more than Sansa herself.

summary: How can you justify Sansa in first book? Now I get it that she was just a teenager & has come this far & I really never hated...
question: How can you justify Sansa in first book? Now I get it that she was just a teenager & has come this far & I really never hated her but only dislike in the first book coz I got the impression she believed that ned has committed treason, Robb & cat are rebelling & are being treasonous. Like yes she's trying to save her dad but still she believed that her own family was doing wrong. Meaning she would be ok with ned being sent to wall & live happily with joffery, even Jon feels that's it's injustice
answer:
to strip ned off winterfell. Rest of his children, wife & Northerners believe ned but she doesn’t. She thinks that ned & Robb are traitors. Another thing I disagree with that she did the right thing by siding with neither joff nor Arya coz she neither want to go against her family & nor her future husband/in laws. I think she did to impress joff. That & the letter she wrote has more to do with wanting to elevate herself in joff’s eyes. Lastly her telling the truth could'v save mycah & lady life.             

Dear nonny,

How can justify Sansa in the first book? You said it yourself : She was a teenager.

When I was 17 (5 years older than canon Sansa) I was head over heels for a boy who had zero interest in me and it took me the better part of a year to claw my way out of my romantic imaginations. I had no connection to reality and I interpreted everything he did as pointing towards him being as much in love as me. And I’m a fairly rational person.

Anyway I beg to differ in several points.

First of all, the incident at the Trident : Sansa is not the only one to blame, if you go around and throw around blame.

There is Ned: He goes south to investigate Jon Arryn’s murder and does not warn his daughters, not a hint. Remember that Arya does not know either, she is just more suspicious than Sansa, but she hasn’t been told that she’ll marry into the Baratheon family. Ned might have felt that he could not share his secrets, and he didn’t want to raise suspicions by not taking his daughters, but at least he could have warned his daughter Arya that the easy way of Winterfell was over. They were not in the North any more where his will was law, but in the South with the King. And he did not warn Arya that she should be more careful with her friends. In fact he left all the education to Septa Mordane who was also not in the know. And he trusted Robert. That was sub-par parenting on Ned’s side, although I love him and he is still far above any father in Westeros (with the exception of Sam). At the hearing about the incident he expects his daughter Sansa who told him everything in the safety of his arms probably, that she should repeat her testimony in full court. He does not entertain the idea that Robert might judge different than he himself.

Then there is Catelyn. I love Catelyn and my headcanon is that she would have given the girls several lectures before her departure. But she was devastated by Bran’s fall and did not do this. Arya sort of ran into an open knife because of it.

Then there is Joffrey who made Sansa drunk and really showed his classicism towards Arya’s friend.

Then there is Cersei with her misconception of what a loving mother should do who pushes for a punishment of Arya instead of correcting her own kid. Arya was lucky that she was found by Jory. We later learn through Jaime’s POV that Cersei sent him out to kill Arya.

Then there is Robert who fears a fight with his bitch wife and does not want to go to the bottom of the fight. He later tells Ned that he knew that his son was to blame. How many times did he not punish his son for doing shit because he feared his wife? - I am not condoning hitting him, but Joffrey became what he was because he was always told that he was the Prince.

Arya should not have asked Mycah to play with her. The royal progression was not Winterfell and Mycah could not tell a Lord’s daughter no. It is a minor fault because Arya didn’t know but it is something that contributes to the whole mess.

So there is quite a knot to distangle and everyone of the adults is more to blame than the teenagers involved.

Do you honestly think that Cersei would have just forgotten the injury of her son even if Sansa told the truth? Cersei? Do you think that coward Robert would not have given in anyway?

As for Sansa lying, she did not lie, she deflected. She was scared and she did something that she have seen her do twice already: she deflects because Arya did something she was not supposed to do. We see her do it in Arya’s first chapter (athough Arya does not realise that Sansa tries to draw attention away from her talking bad about Joffrey) and in Sansa’s first chapter when she gives an excuse for Arya for not joining in accepting the invitation of the queen.

By the way Mycah was already hunted down by the Hound when Sansa have her testimony. There is no way she could have saved his life. And I don’t think that Sansa telling the truth would have prevented Lady’s death. Cersei wanted blood and Robert was not about to deny it to her, not even for his best friend. Remember he could just have said no to killing an innocent animal, he was the king.

So how can I forgive Sansa for that? Easily by blaming the actual adults who were responsible.

As for the letter. You do remember that Sansa did not know anything? Not that Joffrey was a bastard? Not that her father had been trying to give the throne to Stannis as the rightful heir? She knew about the fight in the streets but she blamed Jaime for that (which is not false!).

She gets seized, seperated from her father and is confronted with his ‘treason’. She doesn’t understand this. She cannot imagine her father betraying Robert and blames the milk of the poppy he got. What is she to do im this situation? And then Cersei and the others in the council play 'good cop, bad cop’… One says she has 'traitor’s blood’ and the other defends her by saying she is a child… Do you fully expect her to not write that letter? She thinks she has a chance to save her brother and mother. Could she have understood that her father didn’t commit treason? Maybe. But she lacked essential information. And it would have been bad timing to protest her father’s innocence and she tried the best she could do. Did she believe her family did wrong? Probably, but she had been taught to look up to authority and she had no way to get at the truth. She was not allowed to see her father. She was frightened and alone and manipulated. And then she daydreamed her situation better and a happy ending by headcanoning her father returning after a short exile.

The situation of the other Starks is different. They have different and better (or worse) information, and they act according to the information they have.

So, yes all in all I find it very easy to excuse Sansa to defend her and to have empathy for her. I’ll never understand this fandom. There are people who burn sacrifices for their fire God, there are people who torture, there are people who kill for their own advancement, there rapists, murderers, people who have no scruples murder against guest right. But somehow a teenage girl which daydreams herself into a better situation, who was kept in the dark by her own father, who did one puberty induced act of rebellion against her father, and who fights with her sister (what a surprise and such a rare crime as well) and she is the fucking worst ™.

I did think Sansa was a brat reading the first book, but I learned to love her and to relate to her by the second book, and several rereads led me to the conclusion that she isn’t even a brat, not more than emo teenage Jon. GRRM has his reasons for molding Sansa into the bad step sister trope of Cinderella. And I think one of them is to hide how important she is.

Sry not sry for disagreeing but this fandom has turned me into a proud member of the

SANSA STARK DEFENCE SQUAD!

And then Cersei and the others in the council play 'good cop, bad cop’… One says she has 'traitor’s blood’ and the other defends her by saying she is a child… Do you fully expect her to not write that letter? I did think Sansa was a brat reading the first book, but I learned to love her and to relate to her by the second book, and several rereads led me to the conclusion that she isn’t even a brat, not more than emo teenage Jon. GRRM has his reasons for molding Sansa into the bad step sister trope of Cinderella. And I think one of them is to hide how important she is.

Sry not sry for disagreeing but this fandom has turned me into a proud member of the

SANSA STARK DEFENCE SQUAD!
trail.content:
to strip ned off winterfell. Rest of his children, wife & Northerners believe ned but she doesn’t. She thinks that ned & Robb are traitors. Another thing I disagree with that she did the right thing by siding with neither joff nor Arya coz she neither want to go against her family & nor her future husband/in laws. I think she did to impress joff. That & the letter she wrote has more to do with wanting to elevate herself in joff’s eyes. Lastly her telling the truth could'v save mycah & lady life.             

Dear nonny,

How can justify Sansa in the first book? You said it yourself : She was a teenager.

When I was 17 (5 years older than canon Sansa) I was head over heels for a boy who had zero interest in me and it took me the better part of a year to claw my way out of my romantic imaginations. I had no connection to reality and I interpreted everything he did as pointing towards him being as much in love as me. And I’m a fairly rational person.

Anyway I beg to differ in several points.

First of all, the incident at the Trident : Sansa is not the only one to blame, if you go around and throw around blame.

There is Ned: He goes south to investigate Jon Arryn’s murder and does not warn his daughters, not a hint. Remember that Arya does not know either, she is just more suspicious than Sansa, but she hasn’t been told that she’ll marry into the Baratheon family. Ned might have felt that he could not share his secrets, and he didn’t want to raise suspicions by not taking his daughters, but at least he could have warned his daughter Arya that the easy way of Winterfell was over. They were not in the North any more where his will was law, but in the South with the King. And he did not warn Arya that she should be more careful with her friends. In fact he left all the education to Septa Mordane who was also not in the know. And he trusted Robert. That was sub-par parenting on Ned’s side, although I love him and he is still far above any father in Westeros (with the exception of Sam). At the hearing about the incident he expects his daughter Sansa who told him everything in the safety of his arms probably, that she should repeat her testimony in full court. He does not entertain the idea that Robert might judge different than he himself.

Then there is Catelyn. I love Catelyn and my headcanon is that she would have given the girls several lectures before her departure. But she was devastated by Bran’s fall and did not do this. Arya sort of ran into an open knife because of it.

Then there is Joffrey who made Sansa drunk and really showed his classicism towards Arya’s friend.

Then there is Cersei with her misconception of what a loving mother should do who pushes for a punishment of Arya instead of correcting her own kid. Arya was lucky that she was found by Jory. We later learn through Jaime’s POV that Cersei sent him out to kill Arya.

Then there is Robert who fears a fight with his bitch wife and does not want to go to the bottom of the fight. He later tells Ned that he knew that his son was to blame. How many times did he not punish his son for doing shit because he feared his wife? - I am not condoning hitting him, but Joffrey became what he was because he was always told that he was the Prince.

Arya should not have asked Mycah to play with her. The royal progression was not Winterfell and Mycah could not tell a Lord’s daughter no. It is a minor fault because Arya didn’t know but it is something that contributes to the whole mess.

So there is quite a knot to distangle and everyone of the adults is more to blame than the teenagers involved.

Do you honestly think that Cersei would have just forgotten the injury of her son even if Sansa told the truth? Cersei? Do you think that coward Robert would not have given in anyway?

As for Sansa lying, she did not lie, she deflected. She was scared and she did something that she have seen her do twice already: she deflects because Arya did something she was not supposed to do. We see her do it in Arya’s first chapter (athough Arya does not realise that Sansa tries to draw attention away from her talking bad about Joffrey) and in Sansa’s first chapter when she gives an excuse for Arya for not joining in accepting the invitation of the queen.

By the way Mycah was already hunted down by the Hound when Sansa have her testimony. There is no way she could have saved his life. And I don’t think that Sansa telling the truth would have prevented Lady’s death. Cersei wanted blood and Robert was not about to deny it to her, not even for his best friend. Remember he could just have said no to killing an innocent animal, he was the king.

So how can I forgive Sansa for that? Easily by blaming the actual adults who were responsible.

As for the letter. You do remember that Sansa did not know anything? Not that Joffrey was a bastard? Not that her father had been trying to give the throne to Stannis as the rightful heir? She knew about the fight in the streets but she blamed Jaime for that (which is not false!).

She gets seized, seperated from her father and is confronted with his ‘treason’. She doesn’t understand this. She cannot imagine her father betraying Robert and blames the milk of the poppy he got. What is she to do im this situation? And then Cersei and the others in the council play 'good cop, bad cop’… One says she has 'traitor’s blood’ and the other defends her by saying she is a child… Do you fully expect her to not write that letter? She thinks she has a chance to save her brother and mother. Could she have understood that her father didn’t commit treason? Maybe. But she lacked essential information. And it would have been bad timing to protest her father’s innocence and she tried the best she could do. Did she believe her family did wrong? Probably, but she had been taught to look up to authority and she had no way to get at the truth. She was not allowed to see her father. She was frightened and alone and manipulated. And then she daydreamed her situation better and a happy ending by headcanoning her father returning after a short exile.

The situation of the other Starks is different. They have different and better (or worse) information, and they act according to the information they have.

So, yes all in all I find it very easy to excuse Sansa to defend her and to have empathy for her. I’ll never understand this fandom. There are people who burn sacrifices for their fire God, there are people who torture, there are people who kill for their own advancement, there rapists, murderers, people who have no scruples murder against guest right. But somehow a teenage girl which daydreams herself into a better situation, who was kept in the dark by her own father, who did one puberty induced act of rebellion against her father, and who fights with her sister (what a surprise and such a rare crime as well) and she is the fucking worst ™.

I did think Sansa was a brat reading the first book, but I learned to love her and to relate to her by the second book, and several rereads led me to the conclusion that she isn’t even a brat, not more than emo teenage Jon. GRRM has his reasons for molding Sansa into the bad step sister trope of Cinderella. And I think one of them is to hide how important she is.

Sry not sry for disagreeing but this fandom has turned me into a proud member of the

SANSA STARK DEFENCE SQUAD!

summary: In the trailer, there is a running shot of Jon running towards something but he doesn't have his Armor on. So may be that shot...
question: In the trailer, there is a running shot of Jon running towards something but he doesn't have his Armor on. So may be that shot is taken after the battle when he finally realizes that Sansa is in danger?
answer:
Dear nonny,

could be, could be. I try not to get over board with theories. The temptation is there though, the trailer did not give us much that we didn’t expect (GC, fight with WW, dragons). And I love speculating that we’ll see Jon in panic over a vanished Sansa….

Thanks for the ask!

summary:
aprilshipper replied to your post “I don’t really get the Jonsa/Jonerys fights because Sansa and Dany are...”
                  ...
body:
aprilshipper replied to your post “I don’t really get the Jonsa/Jonerys fights because Sansa and Dany are…”
I am a little different. In a recent rewatch, I really found Dany to be boring but my interest in Sansa’s story really increased. I like Jon well enough, but it is basically so that he can serve the story or work as a warrior to keep others safe. I don’t care fundamentally about his character…or Dany’s really anymore. I guess I could care less about those two getting together. I just want a good storyline for Sansa and, like you, becoming her mom is not it.

I get this. Even though I loved Dany in the earlier seasons, my interest in her story has waned quite a bit since season 5 or so. I’m not sure if it’s the writing or that I feel her character stopped developing a while ago. Still. I find her more interesting as a character than Jon. And I’m not completely annoyed by Jon, because like you, I can see his purpose in the story - even if I’m not particularly interested in him as a character. My interest in Sansa has just kept going up during each season and I think there’s many twists and turns her character can still take, which is what makes her so interesting. Dany’s motives are pretty much set in stone since season 2. I’m not 100% sure what Sansa wants yet, or what she’ll do. And watching her figure stuff out in increasingly tough situations has been very interesting. I wasn’t incredibly fond of Catelyn as a character, and I would be disappointed to see Sansa simply become her mother at the end. I don’t know why some Jonsa fans hate this idea, but I personally would love to see Sansa become more manipulative and savvy and reach her full potential as a player. I like the idea that she isn’t 100% loyal to Jon, because, why would she be? Why should Jon get to be Lord of Winterfell or w/ever when she’s the eldest trueborn Stark and also the one with political smarts.
